unnormalised: Okay, so you're planning a trip to India, that's awesome! And figuring out where to stay is a big part of it, right? I've been there, done that, and let me tell you, nailing down the address details can be a bit tricky, especially if you're dealing with smaller towns or rural areas. So, I'm gonna share some tips I've picked up along the way.
normalised: Okay, so you're planning a trip to India, that's awesome! And figuring out where to stay is a big part of it, right? I've been there, done that, and let me tell you, nailing down the address details can be a bit tricky, especially if you're dealing with smaller towns or rural areas. So, I'm gonna share some tips I've picked up along the way.

unnormalised: First things first, always, *always* double-check the address listed online. A lot of times, the address might just be something like "Near Main Bazaar, Jaipur, Rajasthan" or "Behind Hanuman Temple, Gokarna, Karnataka". Which, honestly, isn't super helpful when you're trying to plug it into Google Maps at 2 AM after a long flight! See if you can find more specifics, like "24, Sardar Patel Marg, C Scheme, Jaipur, Rajasthan, 302001". The more details, the better.

Which, honestly, isn't super helpful when you're trying to plug it into Google Maps at two A-M after a long flight! See if you can find more specifics, like "twenty four, Sardar Patel Marg, C Scheme, Jaipur, Rajasthan, three zero two zero zero one". The more details, the better.

unnormalised: Speaking of postal codes, don't underestimate their importance! In India, the PIN code (Postal Index Number) is crucial for accurate delivery and location finding. Even if you have a vague address like "Opposite SBI Bank, Mall Road, Mussoorie," the PIN code, say "248179" makes it much easier for drivers and locals to guide you. Make sure it’s right!
normalised: Speaking of postal codes, don't underestimate their importance! In India, the P-I-N code (Postal Index Number) is crucial for accurate delivery and location finding. Even if you have a vague address like "Opposite S-B-I Bank, Mall Road, Mussoorie," the P-I-N code, say "two four eight one seven nine" makes it much easier for drivers and locals to guide you. Make sure it's right!

unnormalised: Another thing I’ve learned is that calling ahead is your best friend. Confirm your booking and, more importantly, ask for detailed directions. Don't be shy about asking for landmarks. Sometimes, a hotel will be known more for its proximity to a famous tea stall or a particular landmark than its actual street number. Get them to give you directions that include things like, "Turn right after the Vodafone store" or "It's the blue building next to the Bata showroom".

unnormalised: And hey, don't expect every place to have a perfectly numbered system like you might be used to back home. Sometimes, addresses can be a bit… creative. I once stayed at a guesthouse where the address was essentially "Next to the big banyan tree, near the river, Rishikesh". Luckily, the banyan tree was pretty darn big!

unnormalised: When communicating the address to your auto-rickshaw driver or taxi, it might be easier to mention prominent places nearby rather than the specific address. This has always worked for me. For instance, instead of saying "14/B, Krishna Nagar, 3rd cross lane," you can say, "Near Corporation Bank, Krishna Nagar".
